fr.apteryx.imageio.dicom
Class DicomWriter

Object
  ImageWriter
      DicomWriter
All Implemented Interfaces:
ImageTranscoder
public class DicomWriter
extends ImageWriter

The Dicom encoder.

Instances of DicomWriter are created using DicomWriterSpi.

Possible outputs are :

  • ImageOutputStream
    • for writing part 10 dicom files. If a FileImageOutputStream is supplied, beware to ensure that the underlying file does not exist or is empty, else the DicomWriter could write the DICOM data at the begining of the file, leaving the end as is, which will result in an unreadable DICOM file.
  • StorageSCU or PeerAE
    • for writing to a remote Storage SCP.
  • QueryRetrieveSCP.Operation
    • for responding to a Retrieval request.

Image metadata are not used.

If the format of the image(s) cannot be encoded as a DICOM object (e.g. the sample size is not 8 bits nor 16 bits), an exception is thrown during the write operation.

The written DICOM object belongs to the SOP class specified in the stream metadata. If no stream metadata is supplied or if the supplied stream metadata does not specify the SOP class nor the modality, the writer creates an object of a Secondary Capture or a Ultrasound SOP class depending on the format of the image(s).

If the chosen SOP class is one of the known Storage SOP class, the writer will add any attribute that is missing according to the DICOM standard in order to obtain a conform instance of the SOP class. If the SOP class is not known by the writer, it is the responsability of the user to specify all mandatory attributes in the stream meta data. (see also setNormalization(int) to control this process).

Known Storage SOP classes are :

Computed Radiography Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.1
CT Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.2
Enhanced CT Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.2.1
MR Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.4
Enhanced MR Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.4.1
Nuclear Medicine Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.20
Ultrasound Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.6.1
Ultrasound MultiFrame Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.3.1
Secondary Capture Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.7
Multi-frame Grayscale Byte Secondary Capture Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.7.2
Multi-frame Grayscale Word Secondary Capture Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.7.3
Multi-frame True Color Secondary Capture Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.7.4
X-Ray Angiographic Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.12.1
X-Ray Radiofluoroscopic Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.12.2
RT Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.481.1
Digital X-Ray Image Storage - For Presentation1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.1.1
Digital X-Ray Image Storage - For Processing1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.1.1.1
Digital Mammography Image Storage - For Presentation1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.1.2
Digital Mammography Image Storage - For Processing1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.1.2.1
Digital Intra Oral X-Ray Image Storage - For Presentation1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.1.2
Digital Intra Oral X-Ray Image Storage - For Processing1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.1.2.1
VL Endoscopic Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.77.1.1
VL Photographic Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.77.1.4
VL Microscopic Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.77.1.2
VL Slide Coordinates Microscopic Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.77.1.3
Ophthalmic Photography 8-bit Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.77.1.5.1
Ophthalmic Photography 16-bit Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.77.1.5.2
Positron Emission Tomography Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.4.1.1.128
Hard Copy Grayscale Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.1.30
Hard Copy Color Image Storage1.2.840.10008.5.1.1.29

If the stream metadata contains an attribute that is not a standard DICOM 2007 attribute and was not read from file or received from the network, the VR (value representation) of the attribute is not known and the write operation will fail. In order to be able to write such object, non-standard attributes may be registered using Dictionary.learn.

When writing a sequence, the writing only begins when endWriteSequence() is called.

Arbitrary DICOM objects containing no image can be written using either the DicomWriter specific write(IIOMetadata) method, using the the standard write method and passing null for the image argument, or calling prepareWriteSequence and then immediately endWriteSequence. The object to be written is defined by the DicomMetadata argument that should have been created with a valid SOP class and all necessary attributes as specified by the standard.

When writing an object that was read with some raw values (see DicomReader.setRawValues, QueryRetrieveSCU.setRawValues and StorageSCP.setRawValues) the object is necessarily written using the same transfer syntax the object was read with in the first place, and the attributes will not be checked for conformance with the standard. To write images with raw pixel data value, use the same procedure that when writing non-image objects.

setRawMode

public void setRawMode(boolean b)
Deprecated. The writer now detects automatically if the object to write has raw values or not.

setNormalization

public void setNormalization(int normalization)
Specifies if this writer should attempt to normalize objects according to the DICOM standard before writing them or not. The normalization mainly consists in adding missing (type 1 and type 2) attributes and checking the image format attributes.

If set to NORMALIZE_ALL, normalization will be performed.

If set to NORMALIZE_NONE, normalization will not be performed.

If set to NORMALIZE_NOT_RAW, the object will be normalize if it was not read or received using raw values (see DicomReader.setRawValues, StorageSCP.setRawValues and QueryRetrieveSCU.setRawValues).

If set to NORMALIZE_NEW_INSTANCE (the default), the object will be normalize if it has no SOP instance UID, e.g. if it is not an existing object that was read or received.

Forcing normalization of objects containing raw values using NORMALIZE_ALL will in most cases trigger exceptions when writing occurs.

convertStreamMetadata

public IIOMetadata convertStreamMetadata(IIOMetadata inData,
                                         ImageWriteParam param)
Converts a stream metadata to a Dicom metadata.

If inData is a DicomMetadata, returns a new DicomMetadata with exactly the same SOP class, SOP instance and data elements. Only The PixelData and group length elements are not copied.

Else, if inData is not a DicomMetadata, but supports the standard metadata, a new DicomMetadata is returned with some elements initialized as specified in DicomMetadata.mergeTree.

Else returns null.

Specified by:
convertStreamMetadata in interface ImageTranscoder
Specified by:
convertStreamMetadata in class ImageWriter

setTransferSyntaxes

public void setTransferSyntaxes(String[] ts)
Sets the preferred transfer syntaxes used when writing or sending. Transfer syntaxes are specified by an array of UID strings, in decreasing order of preference. The transfer syntax actually used is the first preferred syntax supported by the plugin and suitable for the object being written or sent (The JPEG baseline transfer syntax will for instance not be suitable for objects with 12-bit pixel data).

An exception is thrown if the object cannot be encoded using any of the specified syntaxes (DicomException with code string ApplicationError).

To ensure that any DICOM object could be written or sent, at least one of the following, always suitable, uncompressed transfer syntaxes must be specified:

  • UID.ExplicitLittleEndianTS
  • UID.ExplicitBigEndianTS
  • UID.ImplicitLittleEndianTS

By default, the list of preferred transfer syntaxes contains these three syntaxes, in order.

If null or an empty array is specified, the default list is restored.

This list is not used when writing back an object with raw values, the syntax the object was encoded with is used instead.

setTransferSyntax

public void setTransferSyntax(String ts)
Convenient replacement for setTransferSyntaxes for specifying a single syntax.

setJPEGQuality

public void setJPEGQuality(float f)
Sets the quality setting when encoding the pixel data in lossy JPEG. The quality index ranges from 0.0 (worst) to 1.0 (best). The default value is 0.75.

getJPEGQuality

public float getJPEGQuality()
Gets the quality setting when encoding the pixel data in lossy JPEG.

See Also:
setJPEGQuality(float)

setJPEG2000EncodingRate

public void setJPEG2000EncodingRate(double rate)
Sets the bitrate in bits-per-pixel when encoding the pixel data in lossy JPEG 2000. The default value is 2.0.

getJPEG2000EncodingRate

public double getJPEG2000EncodingRate()
Gets the bitrate in bits-per-pixel when encoding the pixel data in lossy JPEG 2000.

See Also:
